title: Diaphragm (structural system)
text:
In <a href="structural%20engineering">structural engineering</a>, a diaphragm is a structural element that transmits lateral loads to the vertical resisting elements of a structure (such as <a href="shear%20wall">shear wall</a>s or <a href="Framing%20%28construction%29">frame</a>s). Diaphragms are typically horizontal, but can be sloped such as in a gable roof on a wood structure or concrete ramp in a parking garage. The diaphragm forces tend to be transferred to the vertical resisting elements primarily through in-<a href="Plane%20%28mathematics%29">plane</a> <a href="shear%20stress">shear stress</a>. The most common lateral loads to be resisted are those resulting from <a href="wind">wind</a> and <a href="earthquake">earthquake</a> actions, but other lateral loads such as <a href="lateral%20earth%20pressure">lateral earth pressure</a> or <a href="hydrostatic%20pressure">hydrostatic pressure</a> can also be resisted by diaphragm action.
The diaphragm of a structure often does double duty as the <a href="floor">floor</a> system or <a href="roof">roof</a> system in a <a href="building">building</a>, or the <a href="Deck%20%28bridge%29">deck</a> of a <a href="bridge">bridge</a>, which simultaneously supports gravity loads.
Diaphragms are usually constructed of <a href="plywood">plywood</a> or <a href="oriented%20strand%20board">oriented strand board</a> in <a href="timber%20framing">timber</a> construction; <a href="metal">metal</a> deck or composite metal deck in <a href="structural%20steel">steel</a> construction; or a <a href="concrete%20slab">concrete slab</a> in <a href="reinforced%20concrete">concrete</a> construction. 
The two primary types of diaphragm are flexible and rigid. Flexible diaphragms resist lateral forces depending on the tributary area, irrespective of the flexibility of the members that they are transferring force to. On the other hand, rigid diaphragms transfer load to frames or shear walls depending on their flexibility and their location in the structure. The flexibility of a diaphragm affects the distribution of lateral forces to the vertical components of the lateral force resisting elements in a structure. <a href="http%3A//digitalcommons.calpoly.edu/theses/399">An Investigation of the Influence of Diaphragm Flexibility on Building Design through a Comparison of Forced Vibration Testing and Computational Analysis</a>
